description: This course is a multidisciplinary, interactive study of business ethics within a global economy. A central aim of the course is to enable students to develop a framework to address ethical challenges as they arise within and across different countries. Alternative theories about acting ethically in global environments are presented, and critical current issues are introduced and analyzed. Examples include bribery, global sourcing, environmental sustainability, social reports, intellectual property, e-commerce, and dealing with conflicting standards and values across cultures. As part of this study, the course considers non-Western ethical traditions and practices as they relate to business.
name: INT'L BUSINESS ETHICS

values.comments:
This course is a multidisciplinary, interactive study of business ethics within a global economy. A central aim of the course is to enable students to develop a framework to address ethical challenges as they arise within and across different countries. Alternative theories about acting ethically in global environments are presented, and critical current issues are introduced and analyzed. Examples include bribery, global sourcing, environmental sustainability, social reports, intellectual property, e-commerce, and dealing with conflicting standards and values across cultures. As part of this study, the course considers non-Western ethical traditions and practices as they relate to business.

 Described consistently as a “phenomenal,” “very enjoyable,” and “very structured” class, this course was highly recommended by students for both majors and non-majors. “The use of additional speakers really helped apply the information we were reading,” wrote one student. While many appreciated the opportunity to interact with “students from all levels (undergrad, MBA, Law, etc.),” one student wrote that the diversity of the student body gave the class an “odd” dynamic.

 Professor Robertson received almost completely positive reviews, but several students criticized the format of class discussions. One student described course assignments as “vague” and grading as arbitrary. The general consensus, however, was that it was “a wonderful class” with a manageable workload.
